Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "symbols.nuget.org — SymbolChecksum header required" (#8354) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We’re currently working on .NET support in our CPU profiler (www.superluminal.eu). I’d like to add support for NuGet’s symbol server so that profiling of NuGet packages is entirely transparent to the user. 

We’re currently using dbghelp for symbol server support (SymFindFileInPath) and since NuGet’s symbol server seems to follow the regular symbol server format, I’d expected it to just work. 

However, I’m getting a 403 error for any PDBs I try to get. I know that Visual Studio does support NuGet, so I reverse engineered what that’s doing and it seems NuGet requires a SymbolChecksum header to be present for symbol server GET requests. If I manually send GET requests with this header it indeed works.

I’m aware I can retrieve the checksum from the PE header, but that’s pretty inconvenient as it requires the image file to be present in order to read the checksum, which is not always the case (for example, when examining a ETW trace made on another machine). The checksum also seems redundant, since the PDB signature should already be enough to retrieve the PDB (and indeed that’s how it works in the native case). 

So, I was wondering what the reasoning behind this requirement is, and if it’s possible to somehow opt out of this behaviour?

Not having the requirement for this header would allow client tooling to treat NuGet’s symbol server as “just another symbol server”, rather than requiring special case handling to add the header, which seems desirable to me.

Any input is appreciated!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][UI]No Visual representation is provided for required field 'Username' " (#8181) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1184475
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ​

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450)


## Repro Steps:

    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till "Open Profile drop down" and press enter
    Tab till "API Keys" and Press enter
    Tab till "Create button" and press enter
    Tab till "Key Name" editable field
    Check whether a visual representation like asterisk is provided at the required field "Key Name" or not 

## Actual Results:

No Visual representation is provided for required field 'Username'
## Expected Results:
Visual representation like asterisk should be provided at the required fields.
## User Impact:
Users may not understand if there is no visual representation at the required fields.

## Notes:
This appears to be about adding an * by required fields in forms.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][ARIA]The purpose of the Learn more link is not descriptive" (#8184) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1184490
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ​

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450)


## Repro Steps:

    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till "upload tab" item and press enter
    Tab till "Verify" drop down and press enter.
    Tab till "Learn more" link
    Check whether the purpose of the link is defined by the name of the link or not

## Actual Results:

The purpose of the link is not descriptive for the "Learn more" and "Read more" links

   
## Expected Results:
The purpose of the link should be more descriptive. Screen reader should understand it clearly
## User Impact:
Users with visual disabilities may find it difficult to understand the purpose of the link, if link name is not descriptive.

## Notes
Updating the aria-label in this case to a more descriptive text is sufficient. See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7879 for a similar fix.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Question] is it possible to create a package containing a dotnet tool and a package reference?" (#8352) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

today I have a package that is a console app that people used to download and execute. We converted that to a dotnet tool, but we broke some customers.

Question: is it possible to create a package containing a dotnet tool and a package reference?


Thank you.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue ""Unable to load the service index for source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" in unbuntu" (#8351) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm using **ubuntu 18.04 LTS** and going to build my application using dotnet build
but it pops an error that tells _Unable to load the service index for source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json._
I tried to search the same issue and I found this [thread](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7705). but all comments in this thread show how to fix in windows, not in ubuntu.
could some one tell me the solution in my case? 
thanks

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Make NuGet.PackageManagement available as a .NET Standard package" (#6150) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
It seems that `NuGet.PackageManagement` is the only package in the client libraries that does not have .NET Standard support. It would be great to be able to use this package in other .NET Standard libraries, or in .NET Core apps, etc.

I notice that this package has a dependency on `Microsoft.Web.Xdt`. Is that the only thing blocking this from happening?

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How do I define an internal assembly in a NuGet package?" (#10381) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/sdk#14906**
- Please respond to @lg2de.

---

_From @lg2de on Wednesday, December 9, 2020 5:12:25 PM_

I want to define a NuGet package that contains two assemblies, one that is directly referenced by the consumer of my package and another one that is only needed at runtime and its APIs should not be visible to the consumer.

I've created a github repository to demonstrate the constellation in detail:
https://github.com/lg2de/NuGetDependencyDemo

The assembly `BaseLibrary` is directly referenced by the assembly `DependentLibrary`.
`BaseLibrary` is an external assembly not available as NuGet package.
From `DependentLibrary` my NuGet package is created.

When creating project just referencing the NuGet package, the assembly `BaseLibrary` is missing in the build output. (In the mentioned repository you can find this constellation [here][1].)
Of course, in this case the application raises an `FileNotFoundException` for `BaseLibrary`.

So I've added is to my NuGet package [using targets file directive][2].

```xml
<Project xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
  <ItemGroup>
    <None Include="$(MSBuildThisFileDirectory)BaseLibrary.dll" Visible="false">
      <CopyToOutputDirectory>PreserveNewest</CopyToOutputDirectory>
    </None>
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

The assembly now available in the output folder, but I still get the same `FileNotFoundException`.
This seems to be new behavior in dotnetcore: Assemblies are not implicitly loaded.
The assembly is missing in `ConsoleWithNugetReference.deps.json`.

To solve this now have to [load manually before it is first used][3].

```c#
var location = Path.GetDirectoryName(typeof(Program).Assembly.Location);
AssemblyLoadContext.Default.LoadFromAssemblyPath(Path.Combine(location!, "BaseLibrary.dll"));
```

All this is very complicated and tedious!

So, how can I define a NuGet package that contains two assemblies, one that is directly referenced by the consumer of my package and another one that is only needed at runtime and its APIs should not be visible to the consumer?


  [1]: https://github.com/lg2de/NuGetDependencyDemo/tree/11962aa812a566efbb5782876692ebb1df574fa9
  [2]: https://github.com/lg2de/NuGetDependencyDemo/commit/0d67ebaf3648d06322844f03a99609dd642506b7
  [3]: https://github.com/lg2de/NuGetDependencyDemo/commit/e2dbc8c0265217164f4022347f1c7e65125e4c7a

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The default version is null after clicking a deprecated package in Browse tab" (#10380) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
VS Version: D16.9\30808.132
NuGet Version: dev-feature-OE.PMUI\5.9.0.13982
OS Version: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H2.
## Installation
1. Install VS D16.9\30808.132: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=4288690&view=ms.vss-build-web.run-extensions-tab
2. Install NuGet Client: \\\ddfiles\drops\NuGet\Drops\CI-Private\NuGet.Client\dev-feature-OE.PMUI\5.9.0.13982
## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
1. Create a C# Class Library (.Net Framework) project.
2. Add a deprecated package source: https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-index/index.json
3. Open PM UI, select the above deprecated package source and search package “test10k” in Browse tab.
## Expected
The default version should show after clicking package “test10k” in Browse tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/102196702-38777b80-3efb-11eb-9d43-dfc091efcc0e.png)
## Actual
The default version is null after clicking package “test10k” in Browse tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/102196834-61980c00-3efb-11eb-9882-c1c1917dfcaa.png)
## Notes:
1. The issue also reproes on C# Console App (.Net Core) project.
2. The issue does not repro on NuGet Client Dev\5.9.0.6981.
3. The issue does not repro on deprecated packages “afine”/”ComplexLicense”/ “ComplexLicenseExpressionWithException”.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The description of “Deprecated” disappears after clicking a deprecated package in Browse tab" (#10379) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
VS Version: D16.9\30808.132
NuGet Version: dev-feature-OE.PMUI\5.9.0.13982
OS Version: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H2.

## Detailed repro steps 
1. Create a C# Class Library (.Net Framework) project.
2. Add a deprecated package source: https://apidev.nugettest.org/v3-index/index.json
3. Open PM UI, select the above deprecated package source and search package “afine” in Browse tab.

## Expected
The description of “Deprecated” should show after clicking package “afine” in Browse tab as below screenshot.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/102194886-cc941380-3ef8-11eb-8e1c-5a65e78a4e68.png)
Notes:
1. The issue also reproes on C# Console App (.Net Core) project.
2. The issue does not repro on NuGet Client Dev Branch.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet should not install unlisted packages" (#7466) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet should not install unlisted packages unless the version number is specified. So the following commands should not add an unlisted nuget package:

`dotnet add package <packageID>`

`nuget install <packageID>`

Events.RelatedBody:

I know that we can remove from cache all packages or packages by local resource: http-cache, global-packages, temp, plugins-cache.

The question is how can I remove only one specific package from the cache, I don't see the option.

I am using right now nuget 5.4.0.6315.

Thanks a lot.

Feeds used:
  C:\Users\fandre\Documents\git\poco-1.10\Foundation

Installing package 'Pocoproject.Poco.Foundation.noarch.1.10.1.nupkg' to 'C:\NuGet'.
Unable to find package 'Pocoproject.Poco.Foundation.noarch.1.10.1.nupkg'
```


NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):
```
C:\Users\fandre\Documents\git\poco-1.10\Foundation>nuget
NuGet Version: 5.5.1.6542

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "No-op restore does not work across dotnet.exe and Visual Studio when there is an "sdk" entry in global.json" (#10373) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: dotnet.exe and VS UI

NuGet version: 5.8.0.6930

dotnet.exe --version: 3.1.404

VS version: 16.8.3

OS version: win10 v20H2 (19042.630)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: Unknown

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a new .NET Core Class Library project in Visual Studio 2019.

2. Add a NuGet package to the project.

3. Save and close the solution.

4. Next to the ".sln" file, add a global.json file with the following content:
```json
{
  "sdk": {
    "version": "3.1.404"
  }
}
```

5. Run `dotnet restore` on the ".sln" file.  If you run it several times, you will see that no-op restore works perfectly.

6. Open the solution in Visual Studio 2019.

7. Run `dotnet restore` on the ".sln" file again.  You will see that no-op restore does not work.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Replace GetService with GetServiceAsync in NuGet.Clients, Part 1" (#10362) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Here addressing "Recommended practice of acquiring VS services is always calling `GetServiceAsync` to avoid the high risk of deadlock". 
Since there are 34 GetService() calls to be replaced in 24 files we're doing it incrementally, this is part1 of [issue#3784](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/3784) .
I'm not going to list which of 34 occurance of `GetService()` calls are addressed now. Because I'm going to created sheet with detailed explanation for how each of 34 instances are addressed, for example some of them may not need to be replaced then I'll explain why.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)
